content.raw:
One concern that I have about planes, as defined by SDF, is that they’re not really planes, neither in specification nor in implementation.

Collision detectors that support “planes” will almost always take advantage of the fact that the plane stretches out infinitely orthogonal to its normal vector. That allows for very efficient and stable collision detection. However, the SDF spec allows us to define a “size” for the plane, which means the underlying collision detectors can’t be allowed to construct an infinite plane. Instead, they have to construct a thin box shape, and they lose all the advantages of a true “plane” geometry \(e.g. it’s easy for fast-moving objects to phase through a thin box, whereas they would not be able to phase through a true plane\).

This concern is mostly an issue with the SDF specification, not an issue with this pull request in particular, but I wanted to voice this concern somewhere to see if anyone else has thoughts, concerns, or suggestions on it.
content.html:
One concern that I have about planes, as defined by SDF, is that they’re not really planes, neither in specification nor in implementation.

Collision detectors that support “planes” will almost always take advantage of the fact that the plane stretches out infinitely orthogonal to its normal vector. That allows for very efficient and stable collision detection. However, the SDF spec allows us to define a “size” for the plane, which means the underlying collision detectors can’t be allowed to construct an infinite plane. Instead, they have to construct a thin box shape, and they lose all the advantages of a true “plane” geometry (e.g. it’s easy for fast-moving objects to phase through a thin box, whereas they would not be able to phase through a true plane).

This concern is mostly an issue with the SDF specification, not an issue with this pull request in particular, but I wanted to voice this concern somewhere to see if anyone else has thoughts, concerns, or suggestions on it.

content.raw: Just to clarify, thin boxes are definitely common, valuable shapes, but I’m concerned that having the specification of “plane” refer to a thin box means we can no longer have a specification of “plane” that refers to a true plane, and by doing so we’re artificially limiting the expressiveness of our API.
content.html: Just to clarify, thin boxes are definitely common, valuable shapes, but I’m concerned that having the specification of “plane” refer to a thin box means we can no longer have a specification of “plane” that refers to a true plane, and by doing so we’re artificially limiting the expressiveness of our API.

content.raw: The size specification is apparently just used for specifying the extents of the visual plane. The collision plane is still supposed to be infinite. This is the case in Gazebo right now. I agree we need to update the documentation on SDF to point that out.
content.html: The size specification is apparently just used for specifying the extents of the visual plane. The collision plane is still supposed to be infinite. This is the case in Gazebo right now. I agree we need to update the documentation on SDF to point that out.

content.raw: Yes, on Gazebo <= 9 rendering is respecting the plane size but physics isn't.
content.html: Yes, on Gazebo <= 9 rendering is respecting the plane size but physics isn't.

content.raw:
Ah, that makes a lot of sense! Documenting that would definitely be valuable.

Right now in the dartsim plugin I’ve been implementing planes as thin boxes in order to respect the SDF specification, but dartsim does have support for true planes, so I’ll switch the implementation to using that.
content.html:
Ah, that makes a lot of sense! Documenting that would definitely be valuable.

Right now in the dartsim plugin I’ve been implementing planes as thin boxes in order to respect the SDF specification, but dartsim does have support for true planes, so I’ll switch the implementation to using that.

content.raw:
Part of the issue may be related [to this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/67/add-support-for-planes/diff#comment-79923948). The dartsim plugin implements the “plane” as a thin box, because I thought that’s what the SDF specification was demanding. Now that I know the size only pertains to rendering, I can change the dartsim plugin implementation to use a plane.

If my guess is correct, objects are more prone to sink into a thin box, because when you penetrate a thin box, the normal vectors of the penetration may be ambiguous, so the collision handler won’t know what direction to push the penetrating shape in. With a plane geometry, the normal vectors are never ambiguous, so you get more stable behavior.

I’ll give this theory a test and report back.
content.html:
Part of the issue may be related to this. The dartsim plugin implements the “plane” as a thin box, because I thought that’s what the SDF specification was demanding. Now that I know the size only pertains to rendering, I can change the dartsim plugin implementation to use a plane.

If my guess is correct, objects are more prone to sink into a thin box, because when you penetrate a thin box, the normal vectors of the penetration may be ambiguous, so the collision handler won’t know what direction to push the penetrating shape in. With a plane geometry, the normal vectors are never ambiguous, so you get more stable behavior.

I’ll give this theory a test and report back.

content.raw:
Follow-up: I’ve noticed that [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/38) fixes what I thought might be the problem, so the penetration is probably just related to correction terms not being strong enough. I’m going to be having a discussion soon with the other dartsim maintainers about making it possible to tune collision handler parameters. That should allow us to fix these kinds of problems.

In the meantime, I’ve been struggling to replicate the issue on my machine because [nothing displays in my gzclient for some reason](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/67/add-support-for-planes/diff#comment-79926579).

**Edit:** [**This suggestion solved it**](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/67/add-support-for-planes/diff#comment-79926811)**.**

content.raw: I think you're missing a `-f` on the arguments to ign-gazebo. So it would be `$ ./ign-gazebo -v 4 -f /home/grey/projects/gz11/src/ign-gazebo/examples/worlds/shapes.sdf`
content.html: I think you're missing a -f on the arguments to ign-gazebo. So it would be $ ./ign-gazebo -v 4 -f /home/grey/projects/gz11/src/ign-gazebo/examples/worlds/shapes.sdf

content.raw:
Yep, that was it, thanks! I was tricked by the output of `./ign-gazebo --help`:

    ign-gazebo -- Run the Gazebo server and GUI.
    
    `ign-gazebo` [options] <world_file>

which implies that you can simply add the world file name after the options.

Also, I tried loading the world from inside `ign-gazebo` using the file selection dialog box, but that also failed to load anything. If that feature isn’t working yet, we may want to have it at least print a warning message that it’s not implemented.
content.html:
Yep, that was it, thanks! I was tricked by the output of ./ign-gazebo --help:

ign-gazebo -- Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`ign-gazebo` [options] <world_file>

which implies that you can simply add the world file name after the options.

Also, I tried loading the world from inside ign-gazebo using the file selection dialog box, but that also failed to load anything. If that feature isn’t working yet, we may want to have it at least print a warning message that it’s not implemented.

content.raw:
I’ve looked into it, and I believe this is the intended behavior, from a “garbage in / garbage out” point of view.

ODE has parameters like ERP that allow you to tune how aggressively it tries to correct for constraint errors, but these “corrections” can have unintended \(and potentially unstable\) dynamics behaviors of their own. These “corrections” are non-physical ad hoc methods to correct for miscellaneous sources of error.

Because of the potential for unintended instability, dartsim doesn’t use those corrective measures. When dealing with colliding bodies, we simply follow the standard [restitution model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coefficient_of_restitution).

The default coefficient of restitution for bodies in dartsim is `0.0`, which means collisions are perfectly inelastic. As a result, two bodies that collide will make no effort to bounce away from each other, but they will also make a point not to penetrate each other any more deeply. In this case, the box is penetrating the plane to begin with, so it seems to have sunk in, but since there is zero restitution, it will remain sunken indefinitely.

Here's what it looks like if I make the coefficient of restitution `0.5`:

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/568080074-gazebo-recording-0.5.gif)
‌

Within a couple rotations, the box has fully left its sunken position in the plane.

Here's what it looks like with a restitution coefficient of `1.0`:

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1028016929-gazebo-recording-1.0.gif)
‌

Within one rotation, the box has fully exited the plane, but it also exhibits some very rubbery bouncing behavior as it goes down the slope.

The changes needed to see these differences can be found on [this branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/branch/infinite_planes_restitution?dest=infinite_planes#diff).

The SDF spec does allow us to [specify the coefficient of restitution](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=collision#bounce_restitution_coefficient), although SDF specifies this per collision geometry, whereas dartsim only allows this to be set per link. I’ve [opened an issue](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/1179) for changing dartsim to specify this per collision geometry, but it may have to wait for release 7.0 since it could break some of the API.
content.html:
I’ve looked into it, and I believe this is the intended behavior, from a “garbage in / garbage out” point of view.

ODE has parameters like ERP that allow you to tune how aggressively it tries to correct for constraint errors, but these “corrections” can have unintended (and potentially unstable) dynamics behaviors of their own. These “corrections” are non-physical ad hoc methods to correct for miscellaneous sources of error.

Because of the potential for unintended instability, dartsim doesn’t use those corrective measures. When dealing with colliding bodies, we simply follow the standard restitution model.

The default coefficient of restitution for bodies in dartsim is 0.0, which means collisions are perfectly inelastic. As a result, two bodies that collide will make no effort to bounce away from each other, but they will also make a point not to penetrate each other any more deeply. In this case, the box is penetrating the plane to begin with, so it seems to have sunk in, but since there is zero restitution, it will remain sunken indefinitely.

Here's what it looks like if I make the coefficient of restitution 0.5:

‌

‌

Within a couple rotations, the box has fully left its sunken position in the plane.

Here's what it looks like with a restitution coefficient of 1.0:

‌

‌

Within one rotation, the box has fully exited the plane, but it also exhibits some very rubbery bouncing behavior as it goes down the slope.

The changes needed to see these differences can be found on this branch.

The SDF spec does allow us to specify the coefficient of restitution, although SDF specifies this per collision geometry, whereas dartsim only allows this to be set per link. I’ve opened an issue for changing dartsim to specify this per collision geometry, but it may have to wait for release 7.0 since it could break some of the API.
